title: Grep
data:
[![Unix manual pages](/images/b/bf/Man_icon.png)](/wiki/File:Man_icon.png "Unix manual pages")

[Unix](/wiki/Unix "Unix") manual for **grep:**

- [FreeBSD](https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=grep)
- [NetBSD](https://man.netbsd.org/cgi-bin/man-cgi?grep)
- [OpenBSD](https://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/man.cgi?query=grep)
- [Linux](https://linux.die.net/man/1/grep)

**grep** is a [Unix](/wiki/Unix "Unix") command-line tool to search in files using regular expression.

In *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, most of the useful source is in src/\*.c and include/\*.h, thus you can grep the sources like this:

```
$ cd /path/to/nethack-3.4.3
$ grep -n regular-expression */*.{c,h}
```

Here is an example of searching for "Drow" in an unbuilt copy of the *[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM")* sources:

```
$ cd /path/to/slashem-0.0.7E7F2
$ grep -n Drow */*.{c,h}
src/u_init.c:1343:          /* Drows can recognize all droven objects */
src/uhitm.c:40:/* Used to control whether Drow's sleep attack should succeed. */
include/you.h:356:      /* KMH -- Drow is now its own role... */
```

It is sometimes useful to use grep to search for in-game messages. Want to know what a "wrenching sensation" is? Try this...

```
$ cd /path/to/nethack-3.4.3
$ grep -n 'wrenching sensation' */*.{c,h}
src/sit.c:248:                      You_feel("a wrenching sensation.");
src/spell.c:116:                You_feel("a wrenching sensation.");
src/teleport.c:847:             You_feel("a wrenching sensation.");
src/teleport.c:869:         You_feel("a wrenching sensation.");
```

It can sometimes be difficult to find something successfully with grep. For example, a grep on `'You feel a wrenching sensation'` fails because NetHack uses the `You_feel` function for those messages.

Sometimes, the use of printf-style formatting also impedes your search. For example, suppose that [you](/wiki/You "You") get the message *"You feel that eating the little dog was a bad idea."*. You grep for it but get no results:

```
$ grep -n 'eating the little dog' */*.{c,h}
$
```

You suspect that the monster is variable. You try again, searching for "bad idea" somewhere in the same line after "eating":

```
$ grep -n 'eating.*bad idea' */*.{c,h}
src/eat.c:486:              You_feel("that eating the %s was a bad idea.", mons[pm].mname);
$ 
```

You may also want to check in all files (including top-level ones:

```
$ grep 'HACKDIR' $(find .)
```

A look around [eat.c#line486](/wiki/Eat.c#line486 "Eat.c") (in [vanilla](/wiki/Vanilla "Vanilla") 3.4.3) shows the following:

```
        switch(pm) {
            case PM_LITTLE_DOG:
            case PM_DOG:
            case PM_LARGE_DOG:
            case PM_KITTEN:
            case PM_HOUSECAT:
            case PM_LARGE_CAT:
                if (!CANNIBAL_ALLOWED()) {
                    You_feel("that eating the %s was a bad idea.", mons[pm].mname);
                    HAggravate_monster |= FROMOUTSIDE;
                }
                break;
```

From this, you guess that message means that you now have the [intrinsic](/wiki/Intrinsic "Intrinsic") of [aggravate monster](/wiki/Aggravate_monster "Aggravate monster"), and that eating a [little dog](/wiki/Little_dog "Little dog"), [dog](/wiki/Dog "Dog"), [large dog](/wiki/Large_dog "Large dog"), [kitten](/wiki/Kitten "Kitten"), [housecat](/wiki/Housecat "Housecat"), or [large cat](/wiki/Large_cat "Large cat") causes it.

If you need to find in what file a certain function is defined, you can grep for the function name, prefixed with a caret, for example:

```
$ grep ^delobj *.c
invent.c:delobj(obj)
$
```
html:
Grep

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Unix manual for grep:
  • FreeBSD
  • NetBSD
  • OpenBSD
  • Linux

grep is a Unix command-line tool to search in files using regular expression.

In NetHack, most of the useful source is in src/*.c and include/*.h, thus you can grep the sources like this: 

$ cd /path/to/nethack-3.4.3
$ grep -n regular-expression */*.{c,h}

Here is an example of searching for "Drow" in an unbuilt copy of the SLASH'EM sources: 

$ cd /path/to/slashem-0.0.7E7F2
$ grep -n Drow */*.{c,h}
src/u_init.c:1343:          /* Drows can recognize all droven objects */
src/uhitm.c:40:/* Used to control whether Drow's sleep attack should succeed. */
include/you.h:356:      /* KMH -- Drow is now its own role... */

It is sometimes useful to use grep to search for in-game messages. Want to know what a "wrenching sensation" is? Try this... 

$ cd /path/to/nethack-3.4.3
$ grep -n 'wrenching sensation' */*.{c,h}
src/sit.c:248:                      You_feel("a wrenching sensation.");
src/spell.c:116:                You_feel("a wrenching sensation.");
src/teleport.c:847:             You_feel("a wrenching sensation.");
src/teleport.c:869:         You_feel("a wrenching sensation.");

It can sometimes be difficult to find something successfully with grep. For example, a grep on 'You feel a wrenching sensation' fails because NetHack uses the You_feel function for those messages.

Sometimes, the use of printf-style formatting also impedes your search. For example, suppose that you get the message "You feel that eating the little dog was a bad idea.". You grep for it but get no results: 

$ grep -n 'eating the little dog' */*.{c,h}
$

You suspect that the monster is variable. You try again, searching for "bad idea" somewhere in the same line after "eating": 

$ grep -n 'eating.*bad idea' */*.{c,h}
src/eat.c:486:              You_feel("that eating the %s was a bad idea.", mons[pm].mname);
$


You may also want to check in all files (including top-level ones: 

$ grep 'HACKDIR' $(find .)

A look around eat.c#line486 (in vanilla 3.4.3) shows the following: 

        switch(pm) {
            case PM_LITTLE_DOG:
            case PM_DOG:
            case PM_LARGE_DOG:
            case PM_KITTEN:
            case PM_HOUSECAT:
            case PM_LARGE_CAT:
                if (!CANNIBAL_ALLOWED()) {
                    You_feel("that eating the %s was a bad idea.", mons[pm].mname);
                    HAggravate_monster |= FROMOUTSIDE;
                }
                break;

From this, you guess that message means that you now have the intrinsic of aggravate monster, and that eating a little dog, dog, large dog, kitten, housecat, or large cat causes it.

If you need to find in what file a certain function is defined, you can grep for the function name, prefixed with a caret, for example: 

$ grep ^delobj *.c
invent.c:delobj(obj)
$

rawPage: {{man|grep}} '''grep''' is a [[Unix]] command-line tool to search in files using regular expression. In ''[[NetHack]]'', most of the useful source is in src/*.c and include/*.h, thus you can grep the sources like this: $ '''cd ''/path/to/''nethack-3.4.3''' $ '''grep -n ''regular-expression'' */*.{c,h}''' Here is an example of searching for "Drow" in an unbuilt copy of the ''[[SLASH'EM]]'' sources: $ '''cd ''/path/to/''slashem-0.0.7E7F2''' $ '''grep -n Drow */*.{c,h}''' src/u_init.c:1343: /* Drows can recognize all droven objects */ src/uhitm.c:40:/* Used to control whether Drow's sleep attack should succeed. */ include/you.h:356: /* KMH -- Drow is now its own role... */ It is sometimes useful to use grep to search for in-game messages. Want to know what a "wrenching sensation" is? Try this... $ '''cd ''/path/to/''nethack-3.4.3''' $ '''grep -n 'wrenching sensation' */*.{c,h}''' src/sit.c:248: You_feel("a wrenching sensation."); src/spell.c:116: You_feel("a wrenching sensation."); src/teleport.c:847: You_feel("a wrenching sensation."); src/teleport.c:869: You_feel("a wrenching sensation."); It can sometimes be difficult to find something successfully with grep. For example, a grep on 'You feel a wrenching sensation' fails because NetHack uses the You_feel function for those messages. Sometimes, the use of printf-style formatting also impedes your search. For example, suppose that [[you]] get the message ''"You feel that eating the little dog was a bad idea."''. You grep for it but get no results: $ '''grep -n 'eating the little dog' */*.{c,h}''' $ You suspect that the monster is variable. You try again, searching for "bad idea" somewhere in the same line after "eating": $ '''grep -n 'eating.*bad idea' */*.{c,h}''' src/eat.c:486: You_feel("that eating the %s was a bad idea.", mons[pm].mname); $ You may also want to check in all files (including top-level ones: $ '''grep 'HACKDIR' $(find .) A look around [[eat.c#line486]] (in [[vanilla]] 3.4.3) shows the following: switch(pm) { case PM_LITTLE_DOG: case PM_DOG: case PM_LARGE_DOG: case PM_KITTEN: case PM_HOUSECAT: case PM_LARGE_CAT: if (!CANNIBAL_ALLOWED()) { You_feel("that eating the %s was a bad idea.", mons[pm].mname); HAggravate_monster |= FROMOUTSIDE; } break; From this, you guess that message means that you now have the [[intrinsic]] of [[aggravate monster]], and that eating a [[little dog]], [[dog]], [[large dog]], [[kitten]], [[housecat]], or [[large cat]] causes it. If you need to find in what file a certain function is defined, you can grep for the function name, prefixed with a caret, for example: $ '''grep ^delobj *.c''' invent.c:delobj(obj) $ [[Category:Development]]
